Description: Lid sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; interior reserved; exterior, from top: tongue pattern with trace of added red; below, two narrow bands; black-figure frieze of sphinxes to left (on left, tail of one sphinx, at right, head and chest of second; added red on hair and chest); incised pendant and full rosettes with red centres as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Boardman notes that the sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G120.6 and AN1896-1908-G120.20. The creatures on this sherd are more likely to represent sphinxes since the figure on the far left has a tail and the figure on the right has a curlicue which is also seen on sirens in general but not on the sirens depicted on AN1896-1908-G120.6. Lemos places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless. The rosette on vases of Stage 1 appears casual.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 314, no. 1343, pl. 174 (top left))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2133) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
